title.narrative: FGG SOMO ToC 2: Improved Trade and Investment

description.narrative: SOMO will work together with the other members of the Fair, Green and Global Alliance to ensure that trade and investment advances socially just, inclusive and environmentally sustainable development. Governments must be able to regulate in society’s interest. The current global trade and investment regime has helped create and exacerbate governance gaps that adversely affect society, expanding the rights of corporations while diminishing the policy options available to governments. Policies promoting trade and investment have overlooked the potentiality of negative impacts, putting them at odds with commitments on policy coherence for development. SOMO contributes to this goal through strategies on trade and investment treaties and agreements, and on theme-specific policies affecting trade and investment. Activities include doing research, capacity building, advocacy, organizing public events, facilitate the exchange of information, filing complaints at judicial or non-judicial complaint mechanisms, and contributing to the activities of the other FGG members. The work in this program is organized in dossiers to enable cooperation between alliance members. The specific activities of SOMO are described below. In the dossier Towards trade justice and democracy: Challenging the current free trade model, SOMO will work on developing research evidence and policy proposals for economic justice solutions and communicating and making visible existing sustainable economy initiatives built upon economic justice principles, such as those included in the Alternative Trade Model. SOMO will specifically research and expose the impacts of financial sector deregulation and regulatory cooperation in Free Trade Agreements and their impacts for global public goods (e.g. financial stability) and developing countries. In the dossier Towards an alternative investment model: Challenging investors’ rights, SOMO and her (FGG) partners will foster knowledge development by monitoring and researching government policies such as the EU investor-state dispute settlement mechanism (ISDS) reform agenda and state of play of ISDS negotiations between the EU and key Southern countries. Together with Southern partners, the FGG members will produce analysis of the investment chapters in TTIP and CETA negotiations and other activities to challenge ISDS. These activities will contribute to increasing capacity of civil society actors as well as to the development of alternative policy approaches to the current trade and investment regime. SOMO will campaign on ISDS and work on media outreach. SOMO together with Indonesian partners will carry out research on impacts of investment policies and investment treaty provisions in Indonesia. Additionally, SOMO will carry out joint lobby and advocacy towards European institutions, in the Netherlands and Indonesia with the aim to end the harmful impact of investment treaties and propose alternatives. In the dossier Climate and energy: Transitioning to more socially and environmentally just energy systems, SOMO will conduct research on the links and relationships between different corporate and state actors in various national energy systems and energy supply chains in order to identify the drivers behind unsustainable energy projects. SOMO will document and publish the behaviour of corporate and state actors who drive the unsustainable energy systems, and who have an interest in the continuation of these unsustainable practices. SOMO in collaboration with TNI will conduct research on the local impacts of energy-related projects that will benefit advocacy and enforce interventions by other FGG members and partners.

Alternative approaches to the current trade and investment regime—which are people-driven, gender inclusive and sustainable policies and practices that improve policy coherence for development, such as the Alternative Trade Mandate—have been developed, piloted and promoted by FGG and civil society actors.

comment.narrative: Through collaborative research and media outlets together with a local partner in Indonesia, 1 alternative trade mandate to the current trade and investment regime are supported in influential areas in 1 LLMIC was developed in 2017. SOMO’s contribution to this result came from strong long lasting cooperation and mutual capacity building work in the realm of trade and investment.

Two alternative approaches to the current trade and investment regime have been developed with CSOs in India and Indonesia. These approaches have been promoted via: a free-to-download book (published by an Indian CSO with financial support from SOMO) that includes for incorporating human rights obligations into BITs and provides an up-to-date account of the model BIT reviews undertaken by South Africa, India and Indonesia and which will be the basis of a dialogue among government officials, legal experts drawn from academia, international organizations and civil society groups in India and beyond; a conference organized by an Indonesian civil society organisation in January 2016 (supported and attended by SOMO) focused on the use of human rights and in particular ETOs as arguments in processes to negotiate, review, or revoke IIAs and FTAs; and two booklets, media communications, co-organisation of the TTIP-Alarm Festival where 250 people discussed in a masterclass 'Alternative Trade and Sustainable Economics’ featuring alternatives such as the Alternative Trade Mandate, and mobilisation on 22 October of 6000 citizens to demonstrate against TTIP and other free trade agreements and build support for an alternative approach to the current trade and investment regime in the Netherlands.
3 alternative approaches to tax treaties and international investment proposals, and transparency policy changes and attitudes developed with CSOs.

(5)SOMO participated as observer in the deliberations of Working Group III in the UNCITRAL process on ISDS reform. SOMO, together with academics and NGOS in the Working Group, successfully advocated towards participating governments, particularly from LLMICs, to expand the agenda with wider issues such as regulatory chill, investor obligations and counterclaims, and better alignment with overarching frameworks of SDGs and Paris climate agreement. During the April session, SOMO organized together with ClientEarth, FOEE and Public Citizen a side event about the virtues and pitfalls of the EU proposal for a Multilateral Investment Court, with participation of at least 40 people, among which the European Commission, academic experts, NGO representative, and at least (5) representatives of LLIMC governments.
(1)SOMO participated (main messages formulation and co-development of flyer) in the preparation and launch of a European campaign to Stop ISDS, to raise awareness about continued social resistance against ISDS and to call for binding regulation for TNCs, including a UN Treaty on Business and Human Rights. More than 150 CSOs and trade unions from Europe participated. The campaign centred on a petition directed at European governments and parliaments, which was signed by almost 900,000. SOMO participated also in the Dutch part of the campaign, together with FNV, Handel Anders, ActionAid, TNI, Both Ends, Milieudefensie and others, which was kicked-off in January 2019 with an action in front the Vredespaleis in Den Haag. The impact of ISDS on LLMICs, and particularly on women's rights, was highlighted during the campaign. SOMO also published an op-ed in Trouw (1) about the lack of EU commitment to the UN Binding Treaty and contrasting it to the strong commitment of the EU on the Multilateral Investment Court for investors, which was accompanied by a short video on social media.

*(1) Dutch Parliamentarians have demanded a just energy transition. *(1) Canadian, Mongolian, Australian and international journalists as well as bloggers discuss SOMO and their partner organisation's report “Mining Taxes – The case of Oyu Tolgoi and profitable tax avoidance by Rio Tinto in Mongolia” and its recommendations and react to it, both favorably and critically.
*(1) State Secretary of finance Snel promises to ensure the inclusion of anti-abuse provisions in Dutch treaties in response to the seven questions from SP and Groen Links in February 2018 concerning mailbox companies and tax evasion. The SP and Groen links cited the SOMO report Mining Taxes. This report recommends that in negotiating a new treaty with Mongolia, the Dutch government should refrain from (i) negotiating a reduction in withholding taxes, (ii) providing Rio Tinto with fiscal benefits, (iii) that it should make public any tax agreements or ruling it provides Rio Tinto, and (iv) implement the anti-abuse rule and make double non-taxation impossible.

comment.narrative: (1) 1 CSO Indonesia for Global Justice (IGJ) has strengthened capacities to identify and monitor potential human rights impacts, and especially impacts on gender equality, of free trade agreements. Research activities involved two academics from local universities (Atma Jaya Yogyakarta and Dinopegoro University) and focus groups with 7 CSOs (KIARA, FPBI, Prakarsa, Auriga, Jatam, Serikat Petani Indonesia, TWN Indonesia) and several local private sector actors (in manufacturing) and local government actors. The project resulted in one research report containing a Human Rights Impact Assessment (HRIA) Tool as output. This tool will be very important for next advocacy work by IGJ in Indonesia. SOMO contributed to the project by providing financial assistance, comments and suggestions on the research, and linking the work of IGJ to the work of other CSOs in Europe working on human rights aspects of trade. (2)SOMO participated and gave a workshop on 'Tax Reform Campaign in extractive industries in Mongolia’ in June 2019. This was follow-up to a tax research training done by SOMO and Oxfam Novib in Bali in 2018, organised with Mongolian CSO activists and trade unionists. At the workshop, representatives from trade unions mainly in public sector and mining sector; and CSOs examined together the state of revenue in Mongolia in relation to lost revenues due to tax avoidance by the multinational; and considered a joint campaigning strategy, which will lead to delivery of quality public services and just wages and conditions to workers. The information and skill sharing during the workshop was used in meetings with politicians (MPs and Ministry officials) by the CSO activists (OT Watch) and trade unionists (Federation of Public Employers Trade Union (FPETU), including SOMO, to call for action against Rio Tinto's tax avoidance.

*(1) SOMO's Mongolian partner organisation was invited to share experience in a round-table meeting of university researchers on tax research and articulation of more sustainable economic development opportunities other than extraction and exportation of raw materials. It is the first time that this CSO was included in a forum of scholars , who in general view themselves above civil society researchers and their work. The CSO has also been invited to participate in a national working group on mining resources, in addition to a national audit into tax evasion by the mining company and possible corruption related to the signing of the investment agreement between the Mongolian Government and the mining company. This, as well as being part of the OECD Watch network (which is hosted by SOMO) has supported the CSO in participating and widening its network. The CSO’s director is now frequently approached by journalistic platforms to present the report. Working with SOMO has improved their financial and fiscal analysis skills for which they are now recognized in Mongolia.
*(5) In February 2018, SOMO facilitated and financially contributed to one Indonesian partner organization for organizing meetings in Indonesia to strategize with key stakeholders on the CEPA agreement, and lobby meetings with Indonesian and EU trade officials. In July 2018, SOMO organized similar meetings in Brussels and financially contributed to the visit of two employees of one of SOMO's partner organisations (1) to engage in meetings with key stakeholders and EU trade officials. These activities contributed to the strengthening of that organisation's (and indirectly at least (4) other Indonesian NGOs) capacities to network and advocate on human rights compatibility of EU-Indonesia CEPA agreement. In October, SOMO and their partner organisation submitted a joint position paper to EU and IND trade policy officers. SOMO funds a research project to be carried out by the partner organisation on human rights impact assessment and toolkits for CSO to monitor potentially harmful impact of trade agreements on human rights. SOMO facilitates and financially contributes to the organization of strategy and network meetings, helping to build alliances between European and Indonesian CSOs.

description.narrative: Policies related to trade and investment are improved, so that they advance policy coherence for development.

# mechanisms, policies and regulations improved or introduced by national, regional and international government bodies to ensure policies related to trade and investment advance policy coherence for development in LLMIC's

comment.narrative: (1)SOMO was invited to discuss the Oyu Tolgoi Project with the direct advisor to the President and the speaker of parliament, the Director General of Tax of the Ministry of Finance and the Director of Erdenes Oyu Tolgoi to discuss the Oyu Tolgoi Project. In particular, the fiscal stabilization and ISDS clauses in the OT Investment Agreement, as well as the limited revenues Mongolia can expect from the project. The meetings were held in the week of 10th of June 2019, in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. In November, the Mongolian Parliament passed resolution #92, which demands the review and improvement of all the agreements related to the Oyu Tolgoi Project. (4)SOMO has participated in a parliamentary hearing and formulated several recommendations to improve the Dutch model BIT. Subsequently, the parliament adopted 4 resolutions: mandatory transparency in mediation proceedings; support for SMEs in arbitration proceedings; expectation that non-compliance with OECD Guidelines and UNGPs to be taken into account by arbitral tribunals; explicit promotion of women's rights in BIT negotiations. These resolutions have been reflected in the final version of the Dutch model BIT, published on 22 March 2019. The model is to be used for (re)negotiations with partner countries (mainly LLMICs). SOMO's contribution to the reform of the model BIT was also reflected through advocacy work in the context of the Handel Anders network together with other FGG partners (Milieudefensie, TNI, Both Ends).

*(2) In October 2018, the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs published the revised model BIT. SOMO has worked together with TNI, Both ENDS, and Milieudefensie to improve the model BIT in terms of fairness and sustainability. Among the core messages of the joint work was the proposal to exclude mailbox companies from treaty coverage and to include language on human rights, labour and environment. The final model BIT indeed excludes mailbox companies and includes (non-binding) references to international agreements and standards on HRs, labour and environment. The exclusion of mailbox companies will limit the liability of governments for ISDS claims, particularly in the Global South. The inclusion of SD language will provide guidance to the principles and objectives of the treaties. SOMO has worked for years on these issues, including the conduct of research, lobby activities, SOMO participated actively in the Breed Handelsberaad in which these proposals were frequently presented to the MFA. The Dutch model BIT will undeniably have an effect on future Dutch treaties with partner countries, many in the Global South. SOMO has worked for years together with partner organizations in the Global South in elaborating joint strategies and proposals to improve BITs and harness them for sustainable development. The work done on the Dutch model BIT builds upon these joint efforts and will likely influence future joint work as well.

4 policies were improved to advance trade and investment policy coherence with development policy in LLMICs: 1) The Dutch goverment improved its policy regarding responsible disengagement of power companies from coal suppliers, as laid down in the Action Plan on improving social and environmental conditions in the coal supply chain, which is part of the government’s Dutch coal convenant signed with Dutch power companies. SOMO lobbied to have responsible disenggagement included in the Action Plan. 2) Vattenfall/Nuon and RWE/Essent have taken their first steps in changing their policies and have developed concrete plans for disengaging from coal suppliers causing adverse impact Vattenfall, the parent company of Dutch company NUON, announced that it would temporarily disengage from Colombian coal supplier Drummond due to its failure to comply with human rights standards. Joint work by SOMO and Dutch peace organisation PAX has brought attention to severe problems in the Colombian coal supply chain and in Drummond’s operations specifically. As a result of Vattenfall’s decision, Drummond publicly announced a stronger position against violence in the region where it is operating. In 2016 the energy companies have concluded that a disengagement strategy is dependent on the due diligence processes of the individual companies. The energy companies will explore the possibility of establishing a joint disengagement protocol and will determine whether and how this can be introduced to Bettercoal and to the individual due diligence processes of the energy companies.3) The EC amended its policy related to the investor-state dispute settlement mechanism (ISDS) which it aims to use in BITS with third countries. SOMO contributed to the result though outreach to civil society and a report (2015).

In 2017 through clarified guidance together with local partners 1 policy was changed for guidance for institutional investors. Generally, this new policy explains how to use due diligence at national, regional and international government bodies and aims to ensure policies related to trade and investment advance policy coherence for development in LLMICs. Specifically, this new policy concerns a guidance for institutional investors on how to use due diligence to address adverse social and environmental impacts, such as by disengaging/divesting from companies causing the environmental impacts. Concerns around this policy enabled the opportunities for policy change in various government circles. SOMO’s contribution focused on conducting the research necessary by honing in on responsible disengagement dynamics in the coal supply chain. Ultimately the results of this research were presented to the OECD through written inputs on drafts of the guidance and consultation meetings.
5 national and international government bodies improve policies regarding the energy supply chain and harm full investment treaties to advance policy coherence for development in LLMICs.
